Sun, Moon, and Seven Stars, how do you like me now?—Now forſooth you ſhall hear me Imitate the particular yelpings of ev'ry Dog: This is Kill-buck: Now here's ſweet-lips: here's Ringwood. And here's my Bitch Venus at laſt: Udsneaks, ſhe opens as ſweet as your Ladyſhip.

div.stage: Sings: of all Delights the Earth does yield.
Enter Fancifull, comes up to him, Curtſying.

sp.speaker: L. Fanci.
sp.p: Sr. I beg your pardon I uſe ſo much familiarity with you, upon the ſlender acquintance I have with your perſon.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: A well-bred, well-ſpoken Lady, I fags.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Now muſt I be ſtruck deaf again, if I ſtay with the Larum of her perpetuall tongue.

sp.speaker: La. Fanci.
sp.p: Madam, I am aſham'd to ſee you uſe the Gentleman at this Scurvy rate; I over-heard your jears.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars; I ſcorn to take an affront of any Lady in Chriſtendom—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: He'l beat me anon.—

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: I obſerv'd your proud diſdainfull looks; your Indifferent behaviour—Your Servant ſweet Sir. [Curtſies.] And thus indeed you entertain all your ſervants; as if mankinde was made but for your diverſion.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: A parlous woman Udsneaks.

sp.speaker: La. Fanci.
sp.p: 'Tis well known, Madam; I've had as many Servants as any Lady between this and Tweed, as I may ſay; And I ever receiv'd 'em with all the Civility and Ceremonies Imaginable, Seriouſly. You ought to reſpect a perſon of his Quality and Education;—Your Servant ſweet Sir, your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: She's in the right on't Udsfoot, forſooth, if you go to that; Sun, Moon, and Seven Stars, how do you like me now?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: This is not generouſly done, to ſupplant me thus; but I ſhall leave you to feaſt upon your happineſs, and go mourn my own misfortunes.

sp.speaker: L. Fanci.
sp.p: Really Sir, you're extreamly well dreſt. This is very rich; pardon me ſweet Sir—
This is a very fine Lace;—pray what might this Suit Coſt?

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: I fags I cannot tell, forſooth; But it coſt a power of money forſooth; Sun, Moon and Seven Stars,

sp.speaker: La. Fanci.
sp.p: Seriouſly my Lord Modiſh had juſt ſuch another ſuit on, of all the World, when he firſt made his Court to me.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: How greedily do's ſhe feed on thoſe nauſeous ſcraps of Love? A ſtale Maid, will Catch at any Fool, rather then lead Apes in hell.

div.stage: Toby whispers Fancifull in the ear.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Leave the reſt to my Management;—I'le ſpring the Woodcock, I le warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Dear Sir, pardon me;—I muſt leave you,—Extraordinary Buſineſs calls me aſide, Sir,—You'r the only Perſon I cou'd love to Converſe with, in the whole Town ſeriouſly; your ſervant ſweet Sir, Dear Sir.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: How now Toby; how now Toby? Am not I woundy fine;—Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars how doſt like me now?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: You out-ſhine all the Town-ſparks, and they'l make you the Modell and Pattern of all your gallantry.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Will they ſo? they count me a fool mun Toby, they count me a fool.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: And they'r much in the right on't— [aſide]—well Sir, you have made a fine buſineſs on't yonder; my Lady is ready to run mad; 'tis a ſad thing for Gentlemen to have the aſcendant o're their Miſtreſſes; pray heav'ns ſhe does not miſchief her ſelf about it.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Mollify a little, Sir; be not ſo hard-hearted.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Who I Toby? I hard-hearted? I ſcorn her words: I'me as good a natur'd fellow as lives, If I'm pleas'd, that I am. Tell her, I can forgive her: How doſt like me now, Primroſe? how doſt like me now? [Toby ſtands muſing.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Faith Sir,; I've the prettieſt thing come into my head, juſt now.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: What is't Toby? what is't?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: 'Tis a humour Sir, you'd top to a hair.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: If it be a humour, let me alone for a humour; I'm old Dog, at a humour, Toby.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: O dear Sir; My Lady is ſtrangely taken with pretty odd humours: She'l dye with laughing at you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: You know Sir, your Couzen Sr. John has provided an Entertainment; now I've a diſguiſe for you.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Say no more, let's about it, let's about it. I ſhall make ſpeciall ſport
Toby: Come, come, Sir, 'twill be very taking I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: This Olio of humours, will afford us an excellent feaſt of Mirth; we ſhall laugh our belly's full; Bleſs me! here comes Waspiſh to contribute to't; I'le raiſe a tempeſt in him, Immediately:

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Mortgages, Mortgages; Bonds, Bonds, Bonds; very well I proteſt; O, Udsbodykins, here are the writings of my Eſtate proper; let me ſee,— [reads to himſelf.]—well, it goes all to Mrs Florry,—my pretty little Florry. Udsbodykins wou'd I were at my my 20th. year again.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: I'le quickly put you in another tune, Sir.

div.stage: She gets behind him and ſteals his trumpet from his Girdle; he perceives it, and turns to ſpy her with his glaſs, ſhe ſtill turns with him, and pulls him by the ſleeve ſtill, as ſhe is behinde him.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Snoons, what's this? who is't? Snoons the Devil; I'm abus'd; Villains, Theives, help Murder, murder.

div.stage: She knocks his glaſs out of's hand, he goes to grope for't; ſhe throws him down, and tumbles him about; he ſtrives to get up but can't.
Enter Sr. John Oldfop, leading Florella, Craftmore: Dorinda: La. Fancifull: Loveby, and Donnell.
Florella picks up Waſpiſhes glaſs and helps him up; he beats her.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Have I caught you, have I caught you fury? Snoons, forgive Mrs Florry—I'le hang my ſelf; Snoons, Snoons.

div.stage: looks in's glaſs and ſees 'tis his Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Why wench, thou haſt us'd him unmercifully: He roar'd as loud as Perillus in his Brazen-Bull.

sp.speaker: Sr. John Old.
sp.p: Pray Madam, let's remove this fool;—I have as great an Antipathy againſt an old fool, as ſome perſons have againſt Cheſhire-Cheeſe, or a breſt of mutton;—I'm ready to ſwoon at the ſight of him.

div.stage: he offers to diſturb Waſpiſh, who is all this while fretting.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: On perill of my diſpleaſure Sir, let him alone.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Go fetch the fiddles in.—

sp.speaker: Donnell.
sp.p: Ay, upon my Maker will I joy; and dance all the way.
sp.stage: He dances out; then brings in all the Fiddles ty'd about his waſt, the Fidlers follow, he puſhes them back.
sp.p: Ay by my Shoul, you muſt not come in, my Maſter did but ſend for the Fiddles look thee— [they take their fiddles, one ſings the Song, ſome play ſoft with it.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Sing the Song I order'd you.

lg.l: Strephon the brisk and gay,
Young Strephons Natures wonder, All this while Sr. John walks about admiring himſelf & humouring the Song with Geſtures.
Whoſe eyes let forth, bright flames of Day,
Whoſe ev'ry look does Souls betray,
Or ſplits an heart aſunder.
Strephon has ev'ry Grace,
And wears 'em ſtill about him,
The Nimph whoſe greedy eye doe's trace
The Swarming Beauties of his face,
Yields heav'ns no heav'n without him.
Who views his Miene or Air,
The lovely youth Confounds her,
He is ſo Charming, and ſo fair,
The heedleſs virgin Ʋnaware,
Plays with the darts that wounds her.

sp.p: Madam, there are ſome perſons, that can anſwer the Character. [Oldfop takes Florella: Craftm. Dorinda: Loveby, Primroſe.

sp.speaker: Loveby.
sp.p: Come thou hither; ſecond-hand fin'ry.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: How now Impudence; why ſure I'm not fall'n ſo low in the eſteem of mankinde as not to be thought the fitter perſon to Dance with a Gentleman;—Sir your ſervant, I hope I may Claim the priviledge of your hand.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam; I profeſs I did not ſee your Ladyſhip; Otherwiſe I ſhould have taken care to have avoided you—

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: No excuſe Sir; I'm ſatisfy'd 'twas an overſight: Your ſervant ſweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: They ſay jealouſie is quick-ſighted;—and ſees with as many eyes, as Argus did,—I'le obſerve ev'ry nod, ſmile and glance, that paſſes between 'em—

div.stage: Dulhead comes in his diſguiſe, and Dances ridiculouſly.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p:
Some Groom or Footman dreſs'd up to amuſe us; Kick the
Unſeaſonable, Raſcal out,—his mirth is dull.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: [to Florella] Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars; Do you know me forsooth? How do you like me now?

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Seriouſly; I bluſh to ſee the Gentleman ſo far barbarouſly us'd;—I'le Immediately after him, and give him to underſtand, how your Ladyſhip derides him.

div.stage: Craftmore to Florella—Loveby to Dorinda, after the Dance.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Madam, I hope you'l pardon the Confidence of a ſtranger, If his Curioſity leads him to take a view of thoſe perfections that all the world admires.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Sir, I'm very Certain; there are many thouſand of a Contrary Opinion to your ſelf. I cannot but wonder at the ſtrength of your Imagination, that cou'd ſo ſuddenly create thoſe perfections you ſpeak of.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Pretty little one, why do you ſhun me thus? You fly me as a trembling Fawn wou'd a Tyger, or a Lyon. I do not purſue you to make a prey of you, but to love and embrace you.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Indeed now I do not know what you mean by your fine words, But ſuch a brave Gentleman as you, cannot love me ſure.

sp.speaker: Lo • eb.
sp.p: You need not queſtion the poſſibility of it, when you have already taken poſſeſſion of my heart.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I Confeſs Madam, I have given my faith to a young Lady already; but now I muſt blame my ill Stars they did not firſt guid me to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: O Sir, they were not ſuch blinde guides, they ſaw better things for you.

div.stage: In this time Loveby is toying with Dorin. Courting her in dumb ſhew.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: O Gemini, I can't endure you ſhou'd do ſo; You make me bluſh that you do—Let go my hand, or I vow I'le ſcratch you.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: 'Twill be policy now to retreat, and not to tempt my fortune too boldly; 'Tis in Womans nature to ſhun thoſe that fly them— [aſide] Madam your eyes are nimble Archers; and your Cupid is very Powerfull, ſhou'd I diſcourſe longer with you, I ſhou'd turn Rebell to my firſt flame, and then you might as well ſuſpect I wou'd be falſe to you too.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Wou'd you put in practice the former, I'de put the latter to a venture, and believe you, tho' I were deceiv'd by my Credulity.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Have you any thing to do with that Lady, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Some ſmall bus'neſs only to require the Reſtauration of an heart.

div.stage: Sr. John Sings and Dances—trys to cut the while.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: The Lady Sir, is a propriety.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I have hopes to the Contrary.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Unhand her Sir; I wear a Sword:

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: So do I Sir; in honour of this Lady.

div.stage: lay their hands on their Swords.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Fy Gentlemen, do not render your ſelves guilty of ſo great a Soleciſme in good manners, as to offer to draw in company of Ladys.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: You may hear from me.

div.stage: Craft. and Dorinda go out one way.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: My Sword Sir, ſtall anſwer you.

div.stage: Sr. John Dancing up to Florella.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Thus will I deal out my Love to you eternally; and to you alone—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Conceited Fool; he's grown as old in foppery as in years. He has not heat enough to melt the Snow that lyes on's head.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: And I dare ſwear Madam, he'l ſooner ſtand in need of a Nurſe himſelf, then give any Lady an Occaſion to uſe one—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Doubtleſs Sir; I were over-happy, were I but aſſur'd of your Conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Did all the tempting Beauties, Joyntly ſtrive to ſeduce me; by heav'ns Madam, they ſhou'd not draw me to a diſloyall thought.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I long to be rid of this fool▪ [aſide] Sir, I've buſineſs within; pleaſe you go.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: I wait on you Madam,—But I wou'd firſt inform you, that I purpoſely Contriv'd this match, that you might enjoy the freedom of Love without the Scandall that generally attends our married women; And beſides I have always had a greater reſpect to your birth; and your own particular perſon, then to make the diſhonourable offers of keeping to ſo noble a Lady.

lg.l: Keeping's grown vulgar; Matrimony dull,
Be you my Miſtreſs then—
And you my Fool,
Keeping of fools too, is quite out of faſhion
Yet ſuch a one's a gentile Recreation.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: ACT IV.
SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: HOw lik'd you my Gull Sir?

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I receiv'd I confeſs an unexpected pleaſure and ſatisfaction from thy Improvement of the Blockhead; he was too dull a fool to move laughter before.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: O Sir; Did you but conceive how I wear this brain away in your ſervice, from whence Inventions hourly work out like froth from new-bottl'd Ale; but I'm a man of few words Sir, of few words.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: No more of this; but d'ye hear, as you hope to continue in my favour, do you go on to expoſe him in ſo many Ridiculous ſhapes & changes, that ſhe may deſpiſe and ſcorn him, tho' he cou'd joynture her to both the Indies.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Whereupon I immediately make to my property; poſſeſs him with an opinion of his laſt performance; and ſo draw him into greater abſurdities: But Sir,— [as going, but returns] when you've gotten your Miſtreſs; I ſhall not be your Steward, I warrant, and have the priviledge to cheat you by way of licence.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Be gone; I'le hear no more.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: And put falſe bills of account upon you; till by my Induſtry, I'me poſſeſt of the better part of your Eſtate; and ſtand in Competition with you, in point of precedency, and of being thought the better Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: You'l go—

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I fly, I flye, Sir: [Exit Singing] I ſhew'd 'em ſuch, &c.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: And how did you finde your Miſtreſs? Is ſhe not as I told you, Yielding upon Terms of honour think you?

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: O ſhe was in a melting temper;—But I've ſo Unjuſtly and Scandalouſly abus'd her in my Sham-letter, that if ſhe diſcovers me I'm diſcarded for ever.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: You had beſt betray your ſelf to her, by your unmanly fears; like a Murderer that delivers himſelf into the hands of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Certainly my ill Genius ſet me on writing it, what a madneſs was it elſe, to wound the darling of my Soul; the beſt and tendereſt part of my ſelf; but what doubles my griefs, is to finde my freind perfidious at laſt.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p:
Pardon me Sir, If I differ in opinion from you in that. I'm perſwaded the Gentleman is as far from being perfidious, as your Miſtreſs from
giving him an occaſion of being ſo.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I perceive you're brib'd to ſpeak for him, by your Love.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Were it ſo; I need not be aſham'd to own my flame.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Take care Dorinda, his tongue has a Charm in it; and tho' he has the face of an Angell, and the ſhape of an Cherubin; yet his black ſwoln heart within may be fill'd with rapes, treacheries, and dark deſigns.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: You do ill to accuſe your freind, before you know him guilty.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I cou'd wiſh I had not too juſt an occaſion to ſuſpect him; But I ſhall take ſome meaſures as well to clear my doubt, as to Juſtify or Condemn the honourable thoughts you conceive of him.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: I know not to what Extravagances his jealouſy may hurry him; But if he aims at his life, he ſtrikes at it thro' mine. O Loveby, Mr. Loveby; there's not a letter in his, name but has a Charm in't.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: I am deceiv'd, or I heard the name of Loveby; and know it muſt proceed from her mouth, for ſofteſt Airs of Muſick attended the ſound: why all this coldneſs and ſcorn in your face on a ſuddain? pretty little one.

div.stage: Comes up to her, ſhe ſtarts and looks Innocently again.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: O living dear, you always ſteal upon a body, and do ſo fright me.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange, Madam, that I ſhou'd be ſo dreadfull that at the ſight of me, you ſhou'd be fill'd with ſuch frightfull apprehenſions: I have no ſwinging long tayl, horns and Cloven-feet.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Indeed now I'le not ſtay with you, if you talk of ſuch ugly things.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Prettyeſt Creature, Dearer to me then my own eyes, I'le ſpeak to thee in gentle accents, ſoft as thoſe of Love-ſick Virgins, breathing out their Souls in tendereſt expreſſions, & careſs you gently, as the Morning-dew falls on the opening Roſe, or the fleece of ſnow on the boſom of the cold vale.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: O Gemini! I vow now you ſay ſuch pretty things of all the world as Mr. Bellamore did, when he converted me firſt.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: And dear little Lady, why may not they have the ſame effect?

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Indeed now, I cannot tell forſooth Sir, You • ake me bluſh.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Pretty Modeſty—

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: O living dear, I would not ſtay any longer with you, for a World, ſhou'd Mr. Bellamore come and ſee you, he'd kill you, indeed now—and I am ſo afraid he ſhou'd kill you.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Kindly fear'd Nay, deareſt, you muſt pardon me, if I haſten thus to enjoy my happineſs: There's no one but wou'd arrive at Heaven as ſoon as he cou'd.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Indeed now, but if you will go to Heaven, you muſt dye firſt.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p:
And that I cou'd an hundred times for you, had I ſo many lives,
was I ſure but to paſs the laſt few tranſitory minutes in your dear arms.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: O Leminies! I wonder you are not aſham'd to rumple ones Cloaths ſo.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Oh horrid baſe perſidious Villain; Monſter of Falſhood:

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Nay, your Ladyſhip may partly thank your ſelf for it. As you tender your quiet, Reputation, and Honour, Madam, I beg you'd bridle your paſſion.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Madam, your Servant; you have an angry Cloud ſetl'd on your brow; whence do's it proceed?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I cannot look upon you, Sir, but I think on the Curſed Cauſe of it.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: I hope forſooth you're not anger'd with me; I'le go and ſee after Mr. Bellamore and tell him, that I will.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: I'le after her, I muſt not allow her time to cool again.—
Madam, I'me ſorry to ſee you thus diſcompos'd; and am much more ſo, to finde the ſight of me, ſhould be any way the cauſe of your diſcontent.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Did you obſerve with what Indifferency he left you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Fortune has debarr'd me from the Converſation of witty Men and ſet me up the mark of Fools; ſhe baits me with Apes and Monkies, and I've no ſooner ſhook off one, but a freſh one flys on me with all the fury Imaginable.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: So, ſo, now the wind riſes.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: And they faſten on me by turns, with noiſe, Impertinence, or dull inſipid humours, which they take for wit: Methinks I hate all mankind for thy ſake, perjur'd Craftmore; Oh that I had thee here; I'de tear thee in pieces, thus, falſe-hearted Traytor.

div.stage: ſhe pulls the Letter out, and tears it in pieces.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: There's a way to be reveng'd, cou'd you think on't, Madam?—Think on Revenge,—Revenge is ſweet, Madam. There are other Men in the World, as Proper, Beautifull, and Rich as he, every whit.

sp.speaker: Florell
sp.p: Thou haſt put a ſtrange thought in my head;—Here's one Mr. Bellamore in this Houſe, Servant to Dorinda.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: So, ſo, now is all this bluſt'ring o're, and ſhe's veering to another quarter. Had ſhe as many Lovers, as there are points in the Compaſs, ſhe'de run 'em all over in half an hour— [aſide]—Your Ladyſhip has obſerv'd very well.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: What thin'ſt thou of him Wench?

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: O Madam, He's a ſweet-tongu'd Gentleman, he'd raviſh any woman alive.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Doſt think 'tis feaſible.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Then his limbs are ſo exactly form'd, ſo ſmooth and plyant, you'd ſwear they were made in Wax. There are Legs, Arms, Shoulders, and a body ſtraight as an Arrow:
This ſets her a-gog.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd to try my chance—Could we but contrive to put Dorinda on Loveby, my paſſage were clear. I'le preſently into the Garden, where we may be private and diſcourſe him about it.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: It ſucceeds I'le warrant you, Madam—Vaſtly Rich they ſay, of a great Family, and an Education equall to both. Ne're fear, no veins of flint grow in his heart.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I have reſolv'd what to do;—I'le ſend him a kinde Note; wherein I'le ſignify that a certain Lady has a paſſion for him. And ſee how he entertains that, and make my advances accordingly.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: My very thoughts, Madam; ſomething may be learn'd from his Man—ſeem you nothing concern'd: Entertain all your fools as before, my life for't you have your deſign.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: One can no ſooner ſpeak of a Fool; but he's at hand:

sp.speaker: Dullh.
sp.p: I warrant you forſooth; you took me for a fool, I'm a man of no humour— [Dances as before] Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars; how do you like me now forſooth?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: How Inſipid is the moſt diverting Coxcombs, when we have diſtemper'd minds, like meats to ſick pallats they are all taſtleſs:
Sir, you'l ſpoil the humour, by making it too common.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Madam, Compoſe your ſelf; and don't let ſlip the ſatisfaction you may receive from the performances of ſo compleat a Blockhead: Folly after diſcontent is a ſweetning relliſh, after a bitter potion.

sp.speaker: Dullh.
sp.p: Forſooth, don't you remember a ſtrange perſon in an odd ſort of habit but now; that was I forſooth; I warrant you did not know me. But obſerve, if you hear or ſee any one ſpeak or do any thing, and all the Company laughs, to be ſure that's I forſooth, that's I.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Incorrigible fool.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Madam, you drive the humour too far.

sp.speaker: Dullh.
sp.p: Nay, If you go to that, there be thoſe that can value themſelves, Udsfoot, I can be as touchy as another, that I can; Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars how do you like me now? Farewell to you Udsneaks, if you go to that.

div.stage: Enter Sr. John Oldfop in another ſuit, a Ribband ty'd round his wriſt; with a Locket on't, Donnel and Strain-Conſcience following him; Strain-Conſcience looking demurely.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Raſcall, Dog, If you can't lye for your dayly bread, I've done with you; let me not have you making four faces like a jugler Swallowing knives, put on your praying face: The Demureneſs of your looks will Sanctify a lye.

sp.speaker: Strain-Con.
sp.p: O Conſcience, Conſcience, this Maſter of mine will damn me, that's for Certain.

sp.speaker: Donnell.
sp.p: Chreeſh't bleſh thy ſhweet faiſh; I vil lye for tee joy, what ſhall I lye for tee?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: You cannot now, Madam, let ſullen diſcontent ſit on your brow, when you have ſo many ridiculous objects before you, to diſſolve you into laughter;—So, now it begins to clear up again—

div.stage: Sr. John Oldfop comes up to her

sp.speaker: Sr. John
sp.p: Madam, ſome Extraordinary buſineſs maliciouſly detain'd me from the proſpect of ſo much gallantry; ſome few ſhort viſits I've paid; and let me dye if I could have reſcu'd my ſelf from the Importunities of the fondlings, but upon urging my engagements to your Ladyſhip.
Dog; Remember— [to Strain.

div.stage: He walks about to ſhew his Cloaths, turns the Locket round his wriſt.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: You grace me with your favours, and dazzle me with all this bravery;—You're extreamly proper, really Sir;—Tynſy'd Aſs—

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Severall perſons of quality at Court, think it no diſcredit to their wit and parts in the miſtery of dreſſing to imitate me.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir; If I am too curiouſly bold.
Indeed this is very fine.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: A trifle beſtow'd on me by a Dutcheſs I danc'd with lately at Court.

sp.speaker: Strain-Con.
sp.p: O I will lye now Immoderately; forgive me ſweet Conſcience; Sir there is a Lady,—true; there's an Equivocation— [aſide]—moſt affectionately deſires—ay, good, no doubt, but ſhe does affectionately deſire ſomething— [aſide—To ſpeak—'Tis ſure, If ſhe's enjoyn'd Silence [aſide. with you Sir;—O lo, Olo,—that's a damn'd lye now— [aſide] So that's gone.—

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Did not I Command you Raſcall to deny me to all that enquir'd after me? Her buſineſs, Lodgings, and her name?

sp.speaker: Strain-Con.
sp.p: O lo, O lo; why there 'tis again;—why there 'tis now;—One Madam Cleverwit, that lodges at Mr. Draper-wells, over againſt the Royall Exchange;—O, I lye, I lye, I lye;— [aſide And ſhe begs the honour of a viſit this Afternoon, ſo that's gone too—

sp.speaker: Donnell.
sp.p: Ay by my Shoul and Shaint Patrick; I will go ſhee if thou doſh't lye for my maſhters ſhweet ſake; if thou doſht not, I will make beat on thy fathers Child, look tee dear joy.—

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Excellent ſport—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Let me not detain you from the Arms of your Miſtreſs, All the Ladys I finde, make their Court to you.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: They're all beneath my Conſideration;—No Madam, ſince my Converſation with you, I nauſeate their deſpicable amours;—I'le redeem my ſtray heart; and divorce me from their Cheap Vulgar Love; and the Circle of your Arms ſhall be to me, that of the whole world;—Go on Raſcall, do you ſtick?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I will not hope it;—This Crevat Sir, Is point de Venice, the work is high, and the flower very agreeable.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: A ſlight piece to appear in at the Play-Houſe, or ſo: An Italian Lady preſented me with one worth ſix of it.

sp.speaker: Strain-Con.
sp.p: Mercy on me, no Equivocation:—I will lye abundantly; have patience with me good Satan— [aſide.]—And this very Lady Sir, has ſent you this Ring—O lo,—o lo.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Improbable Sham, this is a preſent from himſelf to himſelf. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Strain-Con.
sp.p: I was almoſt worry'd as I came hither, have patience ſweet Belzebub— [aſide.]—One ſends her Footman to me; the other her Page—I lye— [aſide]—A Third her woman. O lo, O lo, I have two or three ſwinging lies to come yet; Do not twinge me good Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: This is extravagantly ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Strain Con.
sp.p: A fourth begs and Intreats me: In ſhort, Sir, they're grown ſo troubleſome, I cannot go about your buſineſs for 'em—O lo, O lo, there all's out; I have diſcharg'd my Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Donnell.
sp.p: By my Shoul joy I did run to de plaiſh dere over againſt de great plaiſh,; And I did ask after de Laady, but tere waſh no ſuch Laady, by my ſhoul thou diſht lye very much well for my Maſhters ſhweet ſake.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Blund'ring fool, who ſent you on this Errand? Madam, he has miſtaken the place, you may finde by the account he gives; Dull, Incorrigible ſot.

sp.speaker: Donnell.
sp.p: Upon my Shalwation, now I ſhwear by my Maker, and by him that made me, and by the Devil take me too, tou doſh make beat on poor

sp.speaker: Donnell:
sp.p: Much good it may do me.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p:
I ſhall leave you forſooth; If you go to that, Udsfoot: I am a Perſon
that underſtand how to take an affront: Sun, Moon, and Seven Stars; how do you like me now? I ſhall leave you Udsfoot, if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Fan.
sp.p: O me! what did he ſay? what a trembling ſeiz'd my heart, oh, oh,—will he leave us?

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: What means this?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: He is diſtaſted Sir, at ſome words I dropt unawares.

sp.speaker: Duſh.
sp.p: Fool wounds deep forſooth, with men of my temper.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: You muſt bear with ſuch petty affronts, I have been call'd a thouſand Fops, Fools, and Aſſes by Ladies e're now: Come; you muſt be reconcil'd to her.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: I am woundy good-natur'd: I can forgive you forſooth: how do you like me now, Couzen Sr. John?

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Madam; I perceive the Aſs is fickle; and he may diſappoint our long expected joys by his folly;—I'le take order the writings be drawn, and all things in readyneſs for the Solemnity:—pleaſe you to walk dear Madam.

div.stage: Exeunt Sr. John and Florella with Strain-Con. and Donnell.

sp.speaker: La. Fanci.
sp.p: Dear Sir; I thought you was going to deprive us of your good Company, and leave me here, to mourn your abſence.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: No, no; I'm reconcil'd Sweet Lady.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Sweet Lady;—A fine ſpoken Gentleman, that word has Reviv'd me;—I wonder at the ill breeding of Mrs. Florella, to abuſe a Gentleman of your quality, worth, wit, and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Of my worth, wit, and Beauty; Udsfoot ſhe underſtands me I finde.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: That's more then ever you your ſelf did—

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Sir, I proteſt, of the number that ever made Love to me; (and I'le warrant I've had an hundred) you're the only perſon I cou'd ever fancy.

sp.speaker: Dulh
sp.p: Udsfoot, this face has been doated upon by fine Ladies, forſooth, I muſt tell you.

sp.speaker: La. Fanci.
sp.p: Oh Dear Sir, I'm Convinc'd of that by my own affections: But as I was ſaying, you're the only Gentleman I admire; tho' I confeſs my Lord Sparkiſh was a fine perſon: Sir Tymothy Long-Title had his peculiar graces too; Dear Sir, you've an Extraordinary white hand, and your fingers are ſo like Sr. Thomas True-Shapes, ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: So, now there's another blaze of her paſſion; it riſes by ſits like a waſted Candle when 'tis burn'd to the ſnuff.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: But here comes my Engine;—I muſt withdraw.—
Dear Sir your Servant, Servant ſweet Sir.

sp.speaker: Dullh.
sp.p: O Toby! how is't Toby; Did not I humour the buſineſs to a hair juſt now? Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars, how doſt like me now Toby?

sp.speaker: Toby,
sp.p: Faith Sir, I was ready to ſplit my ſides at you. Did you not obſerve how all the Company laugh'd as ſoon as you appear'd?

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: My Couſen Sr. John was angry with me for't; But he's a fool man: He does not underſtand an humour Udsfoot.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Have you found his Equipage where I laid it out for you.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Yes, yes; begin, and I'le ſecond you.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Sir, you may think your pleaſure of my Lady, but I can aſſure you ſhe admires you for your ſhapes; and ſhe's always running 'em o're: and praiſing 'em to her ſelf, tho' ſhe ſays you'r ſomething groſs.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: He's a little Corpulent; but that's eaſily remedy'd; I'le undertake to make you leſs by 3 Inches in a quarter of an hour: It wou'd not be amiſs if your ears were par'd a little.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars, my ears Toby? why, they are not Aſſes ears; no, no; but I care not, If I be taken leſs by 2 or 3 Inches.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: The Gudgeon bites.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I'le do it for you, Immediately Sir; Come pleaſe you to uncaſe a little.

div.stage: While he's Ʋndreſſing; Primroſe fetches in a Ridiculous habit; he laces him in Stays; and dreſſes him Fantaſtically.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Draw in your breath Sir,—Very well—I'le warrant you this will do it.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Why Toby; Udsfoot thou wilt ſqueeze my ribs flat: oh, oh, oh: Udsfoot I ſhall not be able to fetch breath preſently. Thou haſt taken me in above 2 Inches, O, O, O, what a pox doſt mean Toby? ſlack a little; I ſhall ne're be able to endure it, O, O, O!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Nere fear't Sir,—He begins to come to 't;—here's a ſhape now; here's a waſt, Clean and ſlender, — as a Maſt-pole—

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: I believe my Lady is bigger round—A delicate ſhape on my word.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Come Sir, we have but four holes more; patience Sir; patience:

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: O, O, O! Udsneaks Toby, I think I begin to leak at the lower End, O, O, O, hold, hold, hold, my heart will leap out at my mouth, If thou goeſt one hole farther. [as ſcarce able to ſpeak.] I warrant I'm taller now then I was, by 3. or 4. Inches, Udsfoot, O, O, O, don't I ſhoot up?

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: An 'twere Sparagus, I can ſee you grow: May I ne're hang pendant in Ladies ear more, If I think you have your fellow in the three Kingdoms.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p:
Uh, Uh— [ſtrives but can ſcarcely ſpeak.] Unconſcionable Toby,
what doſt mean? O, O, O!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Have patience Sir, you'l quickly maſter this; If I had a minde to 't, I cou'd draw you through a Gold Ring, like an Egg ſteept in Vinegar; come Sir, I'le bate you a hole or two; So, now I know it ſits eaſy:

div.stage: puts on the reſt of the things.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Thou haſt Crampt him I faith

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Now we are gone ſo far Sir; we I ſet another humour on foot, what ſay you?

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: I was juſt thinking on't Udsneaks;—

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: What think you then of Perſonating a deſpairing Lover before your Miſtreſs; I have a willow-Garland ready for 't, And a Copy of Verſes ſo pat to the purpoſe, 'twill be admirable, Sir, 'twill be admirable.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsneaks, O, O, O,—ſo 'twill: But I fear I ſhall ne're be able to Compaſs it, for as I'm a Gentleman, I cou'd ne're endure a written hand in my life,—O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Leave that to my Inſtructions; Come let's in and practice.

div.stage: He puts him in ſeverall Ridiculous poſtures.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: I ſhall be apt, Toby; I ſhall be apt; O, O, O, there was a twinge: Sun Moon and 7 Stars, how do'ſt like me now Toby? how do'ſt like me now?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Excellently well Sir, along, along:

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Senſeleſs Ideot! well; this muſt needs prove very pleaſant; I'le not diſcover it to my Lady, the ſurprize will make it much more diverting.

div.stage: Enter Waſpiſh in a great paſſion; throwing his Cloak, tugging his Ears and ſtamping, &c.
div.p: Bleſs me! here comes the old angry Baboon, his fit's not over yet; this beating of his Miſtreſs, ſticks in his ſtomack ſtill.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: O Unfortunate, Unfortunate; Snoons, Snoons, I'le hang my ſelf, Cut my throat, drown my ſelf; No a little Rats-bane or Sublimated Mecury, Snoons Unfortunate, oh, — oh!—Let me ſee— O Mrs Prim, ſtand my friend Mrs Prim, not a word yet Mrs Prim.—

div.stage: He walks up and down ſtamping, takes his glaſs out and ſpys her.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Now to make this Scene compleatly Comicall, what device Shall I have? O! I have thought on 't—Sir: I doubt 'tis beyond my power to Reconcile my Lady, ſhe vows never to ſee your face again: Oh if you had but heard the wiſhes ſhe utter'd 'twoud have made you tremble.

div.stage: while ſhe ſpeaks he puts his Trumpet to his Ear.

sp.speaker: Waſp.
sp.p: Oh, oh! Do not let me hear 'em then; 'twill be the Death of me, oh, oh!

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: There's one way left yet;—Come Sir, be pacifi'd. You talk'd but now of hanging your ſelf; wou'd you be rul'd by me you ſhou'd Counterfeit the thing; and ſo exactly; It ſhou'd turn more to your advantage then you dream of.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Udsbodikins, ſay you ſo Mrs Prim. any thing, Mrs Prim. any thing; But how may it be done?

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Why look you; 'tis but to be hung by the Arm-pits; holding your head a little on one ſide; pulling your handkercheif over your face: ſtrugling, kicking, and heaving a little.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Udsbodikins; It muſt needs melt her into Compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Then come I; Scream out as affrighted, cut the Rope, Chafe and rub you; and give you ſome Spirits, pretending to fetch you again; The Garden door will be the fitteſt place, becauſe my Lady's now there; ſhe'l be ſure to ſee you Sir.

sp.speaker: Waſp.
sp.p: A pretty Contrivance, I proteſt, A very pretty Contrivance; This muſt needs work upon her;—Come, come, Mrs Prim.

div.stage: The Scene Changes to a Garden.
Enter Florella and Loveby as in diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: And Madam; may I firmly rely on what you ſay?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: As on your Creed Sir, She's ſtrangely enamour'd of you; She was infinitely taken with you this morning in the Park, and ſince, I have overheard her talking of you to her ſelf, like an Uſurer, recounting his darling Sums.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Upon this Aſſurance, Madam; I'le puſh my deſignes on more vigorouſly: But I fear the little Baggage will be talking to me of that Bug-bear-Matrimony; ſhou'd ſhe put it home to me; I ſhou'd be apt to play the Fool, and take the marriage bit into my mouth, if I cou'd not prevail otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Florell
sp.p: O fye Sir; I hope your deſignes are honourable, upon this Condition I promiſe you my aſſiſtance: But otherwiſe, I utterly diſclaim it; She's an Heireſs, and has a plentifull Eſtate I hear.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Is not the firſt Fortune has been ſtoll'n you'd ſay.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: She came this way, and the privacy of the place will allow me the opportunity of diſcloſing my Paſſion more freely: If ſhe ſeems cold, which my laſt Interview confirms me almoſt ſhe will not; I can fall off as faſt as ſhe; or if ſhe offers to make it publick or expoſe me, I can deny it every word: Ha! Sdeath, Loveby! I am Confirm'd now he is falſe.

div.stage: walks along to look for her, Spies Loveby and her together.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I cannot deſpair of ſucceſs, Influenc'd thus by the Encouragement and aſſiſtance of your Ladyſhip: You'l be faithfull and conſtant to your fair promiſes; —your Servant Madam: — Kiſſes her hand and Ex.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: So, he's ſure, —and now he's devoted to my Service. By this means I ſhall be Reveng'd of that baſe faithleſs, black-mouth'd Libeller.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I'le Cruſh this monſter Loveby, or looſe my life in the attempt. Friendſhip I finde is an Aiery notion, that ne're had any other Exiſtence, then in a few letters, the decoy of fools, by which they'r wheadl'd into a belief of the integrity of thoſe very men that intend to prey upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: This is an happy opportunity; I'm reſolv'd I'le take the advantage of an Innocent freedome.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Hold! Yet this Charge may be raſh and groundleſs; I'le try my fortune; but firſt, down ſwelling heart—z. ſighs. — ſo, now I'le venture to ſpeak to her; You'r walking here penſively; thus alone, Madam, ſeems to ſpeak you poſſeſt with Cloudy Melancholly.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: But the approach of you Sir, guilds my face with ſmiles, and drives away all thoſe Clouds you ſpeak of, 'twou'd be as impoſſible to be ſad in your preſence, Sir.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: As for a man not to be in Love in yours, Madam.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I ſhall not be ſo vain, as to think you ſpeak the reall Sentiments of your minde, ſince I underſtand your Love is all diſpos'd of already, to one who has greater Charms and merit, to recommend her to it.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: This is ſtrange and unexpected, ſhe gives ground apace; this ſeems to ſuit with the purport of her Billet. But both perhaps may be forg'd, on purpoſe to make me diſcover my ſelf; but I muſt believe her when 'tis my Int'reſt to do ſo—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I ſee by your grave Conſideration you begin to repent the Charges of your Complement, and the leaſt intimation of your Dorinda, has ſoon brought you back to her arms.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Madam, I confeſs there are ſome ſmall obligations between us; But your Ladyſhip might lay far greater on me by honouring me, with the Title of your Servant.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: The requeſt is ſo modeſt, I ſhall not deny it.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: By heav'ns I'm Conqueror at laſt; I have now the alluring proſpect of all earthly Joys before me, and a few gentle ſteps, will bring me to the Enjoyment of 'em; I am come now to ſomewhat of a knowledge of my ſelf; and am fully Convinc'd, I have wrong'd both my Miſtreſs & my Friend. [aſide.

div.stage: Enter Dulhead and Toby: Dulh. with a willow-Garland in one hand, and a Paper in 'tother.

sp.speaker: Toyy.
sp.p: you Remember the tone.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot Toby: I'le tune 'em I warrant thee.

div.stage: Reads as a Country Clark does a Pſalm.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Go on Sir, yonder ſhe is; How he moves along, as ſtiff as tho' he was in a Caſe of Wainſcot.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: What have we here? O'tis Toby's Machine.

div.stage: Dulh. reads ſcarce able to speak.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: reads.

lg.l: A Willow-Garland thou didſt ſend
Perfum'd laſt day to me;
Which did but only this Portend
I was forſook by thee.

sp.p: Sun, Moon, and 7 Stars; how do you like me now forſooth?

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: What's this? the Pageant of a forſaken Lover, Madam? I wonder you cou'd be ſo hard-hearted, to drive ſuch a handſome witty Gentleman into deſpair, ha, ha, ha!

lg.l: Since ſo it is, I tell thee what,
To Morrow thou ſhalt ſee, O, O, O.
Me wear the Willow, after that
To dye upon the Tree.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: O my Conſcience 'tis Dulhead; 'Twere pity Sir, but you ſhould be, as good as your word.

lg.l: As beaſts unto the Altars go,
With Garlands dreſt, ſo I
Will with my willow wreath alſo,
Come forth and ſweetly dye. O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: The Pſalm's ended.

sp.speaker: Florell
sp.p: If he would but come to the Execution now.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Do you know me forſooth? Sun, Moon and Seaven Stars how do like me now? Was my Couzen Sr. John here now, he'd think ſome body put this into my head now, O, O, O. I'le find him out, and ſhew him the humour, and make him wonder at my Invention.

div.stage: A • he is going out Waſpiſh is diſcover'd, hanging over the Garden-door ſtrugling and kicking; Dulh. ſees him, and ſtarts back.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Madam, pleaſe you to walk this way: A very pleaſant Garden: We are now in a kinde of Paradice.

div.stage: Craft. & Flor. courting in dumb ſhew

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot, what's here? has Waspiſh hang'd himſelf? I warrant if he's found out he'le be try'd for his life; I ſaw a pure Watch he had to day: I'le borrow it, till he has occaſion for't again, O, O, O. Firſt let me try whether he's Compos Mentis or no.

div.stage: He whirls him round, then goes to pick his pocket.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Theives, Theives, I'me robb'd, Murder, Murder.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: O, O! Ghoſt I defy thee, O, O, I ſhall be hang'd that's certain: Udsfoot I'me dead, I'me dead; Ghoſt I defy thee, O, O, O.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: The noiſe came this way—
Ha! here's the old Gentleman hung up like Eraſmus, between Heav'n and Hell; See how he twirles round like a Sparrow roaſting at the end of a packthred; ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I'm confident this is my womans Roguery.
How ſhe has tortur'd the poor old fellow!

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Come Sir, I'le ſave you from the Gallows for once; If you will not make good an old Proverb, and cut my throat for't

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Snoons;—I'le hang you all—O my diſgrace, O my ſhame,—Udsbodikins, I'le e'n fall ſick of the fullens, go to bed and dye with grief, ſnoons, I will.

div.stage: Enter Primroſe with a Letter in haſte.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: O Madam the ſtrangeſt News.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: We have ſeen your device already.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: 'Tis not that I mean, Madam; Do you know that Gentleman? 'Tis Mr. Craftmore.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Am I betray'd— [aſide]—This is pleaſant I'faith, what does your woman mean, Madam?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: The very ſame o'my Conſcience wench, ha, ha, ha! how cam'ſt thee to finde it out?

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Madam, I intercepted this letter by Chance; pleaſe you to read it, 'tis directed to him: Mr. Loveby I hear has given out that he's return'd from travell.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: O this negligent Raſcall, my Cormorant; and am I betray'd by my Friend too?
What means this unreaſonable laughter?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Your unreaſonable preſence Sir; You may put off your diſguiſe; poor Mr. Craftmore; I ſwear you are an excellent Man at an Intrigue: Now wench the buſineſs of the letter, and all is out.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Do you ſee any one making Aſſes ears behinde me, or have I a Fools Cap and Bells on? You wou'd perſwade me I am not my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: No Sir, I wou'd perſuade you, are your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I am the Man, if you'I have it ſo.—But I was never ſo miſtaken in my ſelf, all days of my life before. Do you hear Madam.

div.stage: She throws the Letter, and goes out laughing with Primroſe.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Adieu Sir, Da, da. poor thing, wou'd it have a wife?

sp.speaker: Crat.
sp.p:
O my damn'd careleſs Rogue, and more damn'd treacherous friend.
'Tho' he did not know of my coming to Town, yet he reported it at a venture, perhaps on purpoſe to further his own deſigns—Diſtraction, Diſtraction, Hell and the Devill; I ſhall run mad.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Hey day! what's come to you now?

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: My hopes are all Shipwrack'd, I'm barbarouſly Wrong'd by my Slave and my Friend.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Pardon me if I think you brand his Reputation.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Ay, doat on him ſtill: and may he be as great a plague to you as ſhe has been to me.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Paſſion, paſſion, meer paſſion, and nothing elſe; Be advis'd, and hearken to reaſon.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Ha! what's that? and was her Innocence only pretended, and her ſimplicity affected? The Sex had been amply Reveng'd, had ſhe put falſe Dice upon me; Pox, this is ſome Country-Wench of a decay'd family, and craz'd Reputation;—One that he has debauch'd, and now wou'd put her off upon me, or any one that wou'd be fond of being ruin'd;—'Twas well I diſcover'd her; elſe this Algereen might have taken me with her falſe Colours, and made prize of me i'faith.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I cannot bear the reall falſhood of a pretended friend, therefore I'le demand ſatisfaction of Loveby; and if he cannot defend himſelf with his tongue; let him if he dare, with his Sword.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: Anger is a ſhort madneſs; and 'tis ill truſting a weapon in a Madmans hand: Let either fall, I ſuffer loſs, in this of a Relation; In that, which is ten times more of a Lover: I'le try all ways Imaginable to prevent the threatning ills; and be ſure to Examine all their motions, with a Curious eye.

lg.l: We ought to watch thoſe things we value moſt,
Since they're in danger to be ſooneſt loſt.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: THe Devil's in this ſlippery Jade, fortune; how ſhe juggles and plays faſt and looſe with us: If I cannot bring things about again, I muſt e'en ſhew my threatning Maſter yonder a fair pair of heels;—One of my Fools, I think I have pretty well manag'd already; he was ſhrewdly terrifi'd with the apprehenſions of old Waſpiſh's proceeding againſt him, and poſting into the Country; whereupon for a pretended diſguiſe I have equipt him with an old Ruſty Suit of Armour, which I accidentally met with in the houſe here; and he ſtruts about, and is as proud of it, as a new-liſted foot-Soldier is at the firſt putting on of his Calico-ſaſh, and great ſtinking Braſshilted Sword.

div.stage: Enter Dulhead in Ruſty Armour with a long Spaniſh Sword ſtrutting about the Stage.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum,——hum—hum— [ſtrutting] Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars, how doſt like me now Toby?—hum—hum——

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Oh, It does rarely Sir; only let your gate be ſomewhat ſtiffer, your ſteps larger, and your head a thought higher.——
sp.stage: He puts him in's poſture, Dulhead ſtruts and ſtalks, &c.
sp.p: Admirably well Sir; Be ſure you remember the terms of Art I gave you, your words of terror, and ſo forth, and you are a compleat Bully.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Mum Budget—I warrant thee Toby; Udsfoot I ſhall be a terrible fellow——by Garagantua, Gog, and Magog, hea Toby, hea boy, hea.

div.stage: Dulhead practiſes ſtrutttng and ſtalking about the ſtage crying hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: To a hair Sir, you do it to a hair; I'le leave you to your practiſe.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! hum! Udsfoot, but if he ſhou'd diſcover me at laſt, and apprehend me, he wou'd certainly hang me; and that wou'd be a diſgrace to me all days of my life after—Udsneaks, I had as good into the Country yet I think.

Fanci. How, into the Country, did he ſay? O my misfortunes, I am loſt
for ever, fall roof, and bury me quick in thy ruines—

div.stage: pretends to faint: Dulhead ſtalks to her takes him by the hand, and kiſſes it.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! hum!

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: By this dear hand, you ſhall not go: For upon my word that Buſineſs of Waſpiſhes is made up; He is pacifi'd, and has forgiven you.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! hum! hum!

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: I am amaz'd both at the ſtrangeneſs of his Dreſs and behaviour, ſeriouſly—But oh that Florella, had you heard how ſhe abus'd you.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! Buz, Udsfoot, I ſhall be a woundy Bully: How forſooth; Did ſhe ſo, I defy her—hum! hum! She takes me for a fool belike—hum! hum!

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: She is like the reſt of the young giddy women of the Town that doat on empty Shallow fellows, fine Cloaths and meer out-ſides; and never Conſider the inner and nobler Beauties of the mind; and have no reſpect for perſons of merit, ſuch as your ſelf Sir.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! hum! An Incomparable Lady: Say I met him now; I go up to him, and run full drive againſt him thus: Then I twirl his hat thrice round his head, and give him not a word but Mum Budget:—hum! hum!

div.stage: Runs againſt Fancifull and almoſt beats her down.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: His rude Deportment Confounds me, totally, totally: Sir I perceive; I do not engage or attract your thoughts:

sp.speaker: Dulh
sp.p: Hum! Hum!

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Pleaſe you Sir to honour my Apartment, I can ſhew you ſome ſmall Monuments of my former Servants favours; As a Cabinet of Ebony, the Repoſitory of my Jewells; a Scruto're inlaid with Ivory, and ſtudded with Gold—Beſides ſome choice pieces drawn by the beſt hands in Italy, with my own Picture at the upper-end, and all preſents ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! She is woundy rich: I'le have her, tho' I loſe my Eſtate by it. [aſide] Madam, forſooth, I am in love with you, and will marry you: Toby told me of your perfections before.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Your Servant ſweet Sir, you are the only perſon I cou'd hope wou'd marry me— [aſide]—I'le to my Apartment, and put things in Order for your Reception. Your Servant dear Sir, your Servant.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Oldfop the other way.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot, here's my Couſen Sr. John—he I not know me trow. I'le Bully him—Udsneaks, I'le Bully him—Hum! hum! hum! &c.
sp.stage: Dulh. ſtalks to him, holding up his head, runs upon him.
sp.p: Hum! hum!

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: What vulgar Raſcal has been practiſing upon the Inſenſible?

div.stage: Dulh. walks by him, and hits him on the ſhins with the end of his ſword.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! Buz!

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p:
What a pox ailes the Impertinent?—He is Infatuated; By
heav'ns Infatuated;—Blockhead will you break forth into the Solution of the Enigma.

div.stage: Dulhead comes up to him again, and twirls his hat round his head.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Mum, Budget—hum! hum!

sp.speaker: Sr. John Old.
sp.p: Confound the Irregular Sot, what does he mean? Heark you Sir Diego, my Don Fungoſo,—

div.stage: Dulh. draws and drives him about the ſtage.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Nay then; by Gog and Magog; Garagantua, and the twelve Champions of England: Francanado:—

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Ounds forbear;—

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Paſſado:

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: What the Devil, Couz!

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Palizado:

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Hell and the Devill,—why Cuz. I ſay, Cuz.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Slaſhado;—

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Hold, hold,—

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Parado;—

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Ounds, are you mad?

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Slapado.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: What a pox; nay, nay, nay.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Strapado, Rapado, Baſtinado.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Help, help, what a plague:—hold, hold.

div.stage: Dulhead leaves off, ſtruts as before.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: No, no; I am a Fool, a man of no humour: How do you like me now, Couzen Sr. John?—Paſſado, Strapado, Rapado, Baſtinado:

div.stage: Runs at Sr. John as before.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Nay what a Devil, hold, hold:— prithee Couz. lay by this humour, and ſurrender up thy ſelf to attention a little: Here will be ſome writings preſently which you muſt ſet your hand to; the Lady expects you, and all things are in Readyneſs.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Mum, Budget—No I defy her Couſin Sr. John, I defy her, I have a Lady that is an Angel; and has a woundy deal of plate and Jewells.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Confound her: I fear Fancifull has ſet upon him with all her noiſe and affectation; ſhe is the mother of time; and was Nurſe to Eves firſt child.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Popum Buz: Say you ſo Couſin Sir John, I can ſcarcely believe you tho'.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: A meer toy-ſhop, a Change; and tells you of more Lords & Knights, that have been her Servants, then ever were heard of ſince the order firſt came up.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Then I defy her; I'de have her to know I defy her; I wou'd not have her tho' ſhe had a heap of Gold as high as the Monument; Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars how do you like me now? Couſin Sr. John.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p:
I ſhall take care to ſecure you, leſt my deſigns are fruſtrated: [aſide A few ſwift-wing'd minutes will bring my Lawyer hither, and then I ſhall expect your ready Complyance; now will I prepare to feaſt and wantonly
Riot on all the luſcious Sweets of Love.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot, this is a parlous woman: If the old puſs had gotten me into her Clutches, ſhe'd have claw'd me off woundily, I fag.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: How is this? By what I hear, his Couſin Sir John has work't him off from the Intereſt Fancifull had in him too; It muſt be my Buſineſs to bring him on again.

div.stage: Dulh. ſees Toby: he ſtruts about as before, and twirls his hat round his head.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Hum! hum! Mum Budget: hum!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Heav'ns Sir, you're fortunately met.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Why Toby, what's the matter? hea Toby!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: O Sir, A Damnable plot againſt you.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! Is that all poor Toby, ha, ha, ha! That this fellow ſhou'd be ſuch a fool to think I cou'd not ſmell it out, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Well Sir; you were certainly born with a caul upon your head, elſe my Lady Fancifull,—

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Had made a Fool of me thou think'ſt: Popum.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: All miſtake Sir, all miſtake; Do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: I defy her Toby; I defy her; No; I am juſt come to the point of agreement with Florella;

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: That is the very thing I came to give you a Caution of: For Sir, you muſt know your Couſin Sr. John has Contriv'd to make you ſigne to a Conveyance of part of your Eſtate; and intends to put Primroſe upon you, and marry Florella himſelf: Here ſhe is to witneſs it.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars, a deep deſigne I fags; a peſtilent Contrivance: But Toby; I thought on this buſineſs my ſelf man;—Good wits will jump.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: What he has told you, is very true; upon my word Sir, But they cou'd not win me to ſo baſe, ſo treacherous an Act.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be a Maſter-peice to Countermine 'em, and blow 'em up with their own powder.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot, I was juſt thinking on't Toby.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Therefore the better to further your purpoſe, do you ſeem to aſſent to every thing they propoſe: But what ever you do be ſure to ſecure the writings in your own hands.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot, ſo I will;—Thou art a very honeſt fellow for this, Toby; ha, ha, ha! I can't chuſe but laugh to think how woundily I ſhall ſurprize 'em:—Lericum twang, Buz. ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: So; this Buſineſs is done effectually:
If the Blunderbuſs go off; I'le engage he does Execution.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: No doubt on't, when he is ſo dangerouſly loaded by your worſhip.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p:
Say'ſt thou ſo, my little Nymph-tutelar, of the Dreſſing-box and
pomatums, my gentle veſtal 'oth Fires of Quince and Marmalade;—this rallery ſo becomes that pretty mouth of thine; that I gad Childe I am ſo in love with it, I could e'ne kiſs it again:— [offers to kiſs her]—But after all, Gad you muſt ſtand to me in this Buſineſs of the Letter, or I muſt ne're look my Maſter in the face again.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Oh dear Mr. Toby, the Conſtancy of your love, and the Sincerity of your paſſion, cannot but oblige exceedingly.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Look thee, here's a Letter; and I have Counterfeited the Superſcription ſo exactly, you can't diſtinguiſh it from the true: poſſeſs thy Lady, this was a meer forgery of thy own, and to Convince her, give her this:

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: A goodly work, going on.

sp.speaker: Toby
sp.p: Which when ſhe breaks open; ſhe'le finde to be a blank:—Doſt ſee Primroſe, how theſe yellow Boys ſhine upon thee like ſo many little Suns.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: I am heartily ſorry, the gentlemen are come too late.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ay do, be obſtinate, and refuſe; and become a Scandal to thy profeſſion, do, do.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Well; I'le take 'em for once, that your Maſter may not think me ſo ill-bred, as to refuſe a Gentlemans kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: [Sings] Wou'd I had thee, quoth he?—

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: To your poſt, to your poſt; yonder's my Lady; not a ſmile, a look, or the leaſt token of familiarity.

div.stage: Primroſe and Toby Compoſe their Looks.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Well friend, I muſt needs own your maſter is a non-parile at an Intrigue, we may ſee what great advantages may be reapt from travelling; without doubt he learn'd this Miſtery at the French Court; 'tis ſo far out of the Common road of Amours.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Madam; what means your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, poor Gentleman; he thought he lay ſecure under his diſguiſe, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Aſſiſt me once, good neceſſary Confidence; and bluſhes be as far from me, as ſneaking ill-bred Modeſty is uſually from a Siſter of my profeſſion: [Prim. comes up to her] Madam, I moſt humbly beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: For what? is the wench mad?

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: I Confeſs Madam; I forg'd this Letter but now: but 'twas only to try how you ſtood affected towards Mr. Craftmore.

div.stage: gives her the Letter, ſhe breaks it open, finds a blank.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Well ſaid little Matchiavil; I love and honour thee for this Choice gift of lying—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: How! and durſt you own it huſwife!

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Since 'twas Innocently deſign'd Madam, I purpos'd to diſabuſe your Ladiſhip, and beg your pardon

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: How cou'd you hope I wou'd grant it?

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Upon the knowledge of the ſweetneſs of your Ladyſhips temper.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Aye; tickle her there my little Cockatrice—glibly, glibly—ſtroak her gently and betray her with a ſmile, do, do.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: And am I thus deceiv'd, and put upon by thee too?—Let me hear no more of theſe tricks, If you dare, go to your primitive Knitting Needles.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: I promiſe your Ladyſhip, I ſhall be Cautious for the future in Caſes of this Nature.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Ah, my dear little Devil; let me kiſs and hug thee for this; I muſt confeſs I was Ignorant of thy great abilities before.

div.stage: A noiſe of Claſhing of Swords.
Enter Craftmore and Loveby as fighting; Toby beats down their Swords, Dorinda runs in between them; ſhe and Primroſe ſhrieking out.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Sdeath Sirs what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Now will I to my Lady, and this will Confirm her in the belief of what I told her, and that this is not Mr. Craftmore.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: I beg you, by the panting Souls of thoſe fair virgins that languiſh for you, put up your Swords.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Sir, you have wrong'd a friend of mine, and that in the higheſt nature; even in the right of his love; baſely, in his abſence.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: I underſtand you not Sir:—I wiſh I knew the Gentleman; that I might give him perſonall ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Had you not once a familiarty with one Craftmore?

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Yes Sir; but no one dares think I wou'd print ſuch eternall ſtains upon my honour; as to violate ſo profeſt a friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Did you not attempt to Rival him in the Intereſt of his Love?

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: No Sir; upon my honour, no.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: And to promote your own Amour, did you not (though you know no ſuch thing) ſpread a falſe Report of his return?

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Hell reward me if I did.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: And taking this advantage of his abſence; endeavour to ſeduce his Miſtreſs from him.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: No, Sir, no; perdition Seize me, if it ever enter'd into my thought.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Know Sir, then, that I am he.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Dear, dear, friend; wellcome, wellcome; ten thouſand welcoms.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Dear Loveby forgive me.—

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: As freely as I hope for the pardon of my own Sins.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Upon the aſſurance of your pardon; I'le Inform you at a more Convenient time, of the Unhappy cauſe of this Jealouſy;—this frenzy of mine;—why I us'd this diſguiſe;—for what reaſons I ſent my Couſin Dorinda hither.—

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: How! what an Unlucky Dog am I; now am I aſham'd to look her in the Face? — [bowing to her]—Dear Madam, your pardon for all my Rudeneſs:—

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Why, ſhe put on this mask of Simplicity, and I pretended Courtſhip to her.

sp.speaker: Loveby.
sp.p: Come Faith Ned; you was a little too blame, that you did not give Notice of your being in Town; but to go quits with you, you muſt know I have had ſome ſuſpitions of you too; for when I perceiv'd this Lady's ſimplicity to be affected, I began to harbour diſhonourable thoughts of you both, but now I'm Convinc'd of my Error, and beg you'd Intercede to her for me.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: You had beſt try your own power firſt, Sir.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Encourag'd by you, dear Madam, I dare do much: And here I wou'd make a tender of my whole heart to you.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: O Sir; I ſhall not be ſo unreaſonable to expect, that you a perſon ſo generally receiv'd by the Ladies, can any more confine your ſelf to one woman, then one bottle.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Madam, I confeſs I have been a Rover;—But 'tis like thoſe that travell far thro' other Countrys to come to their own; but when they are there, they fix for ever:—Faith Madam 'twould be a charity in you to reclaim a wilde fellow.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: The Experiment carries ſo much of danger in it, I dare not venture.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: I Confeſs at firſt my deſign was diſhonourable.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: And how can I be aſſur'd 'tis other ways now?

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: To give you a Demonſtration of it, I wou'd renounce my belove • liberty, for your ſake, and venture even to marry you.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: And Repent it the next morning, like a raw acquaintance that has been fuddled with you over night.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Dorinda, diſſemble not any longer; give him your hand.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: He had my heart before.

div.stage: Craft. puts her hand in his.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: And now friend, I have one Requeſt to you, that you wou'd aſſiſt me in my love, as I have you in yours.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: I were unworthy elſe, dear friend—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: How Primroſe! Did you not ſay theſe Gentlemen were engag'd in a quarrell? Methinks 'tis a very loving one.—This Confirms me this is Craftmore; and all is a meer Sham you pretended but now.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: What a turn is here? all's unravell'd again.— [aſide]—Believe me I've delt faithfully with your Ladyſhip.—

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Curſe on ill luck, here's your Miſtreſs; Do you lead Dorinda off, and Immediately ſend me a note; wherein ſignify your Contempt of her, that you're lately arriv'd and marry'd to another. [aſide] Expect me inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha Sir, you may ſtay;—ha, ha, ha!—Well, you're two of the quie • eſt Sons of Mars, I ever ſaw:—L • t me ſee: not ſo much as ſcratching of faces; or biting of thumbs;—prithee wench help me laugh.

sp.speaker: Primr
sp.p: I muſt do it, leſt ſhe ſuſpect I am in the plot againſt her.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip is in a very gay humour.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Really Sir; tho' I muſt needs own 'twas a very Conſiderate thing of you, to prevent the effuſion of Chriſtian blood:—

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: You do not deſign to affront me: I ſhall leave you to the enjoyment of your humour.

div.stage: Enter a Porter with a note.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Is one Mr. Loveby here?

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Some people call me ſo, Sir.

sp.speaker: Port.
sp.p: Here's a note for you Sir.—

div.stage: takes it and gives the Porter mony

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: [Reading as Surpriz'd.—] Dear Jack I've been hunting after thee theſe two days—there's not a Tavern has ſcap't me; I lodge at my Uncle Freelands, by the Temple.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: You ſeem Concern'd.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: Pleaſe you to reade it, I dare believe you'le be ſo too.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: But hearing you was with a Caſt Miſtreſs of mine: [reads] Tell Florella, that I and my Lady intend a viſit within this half hour:—Oh horrid! your faithfull friend Edw. Craftmore.
Oh Inhumane Tyrant! a Turk, or a Cannibal wou'd have treated me more civilly.—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay to hear you now Madam—But faith methinks this was ſomewhat cruelly done of my friend.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: If I be not reveng'd,—But ſeriouſly I thought the Gentleman you parted from was Mr. Craftmore.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: And that I preſume was the cauſe of your laughter: 'tis not generous to be of Counſell againſt my friend; but to ſerve you Madam, there is one way left yet; do you Sollicite young Bellamore; Muſter up your female Arts; ſpread all your nets to entangle him.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I have already attempted it, and but for my folly, I had ſucceeded.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: I can give you greater encouragement than you imagine: You know I made my Court to Dorinda, and at laſt with ſome difficulty, I prevail'd with her to hearken to Conditions: Bellamore perceiv'd it, and gave me a Challenge, which upon her Entreaties I declin'd, and ſeem'd to lay by all pretenſions to her: Upon this he embrac'd me and ſtyl'd me his Friend.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Now Madam, all's out; and you may finde, I am Innocent.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But I only pretended this friendſhip, that I might the more ſecurely deprive him of his Miſtreſs, ſo that if you win him, you make room for me, and Craftmore will be diſappointed of his Inſulting Revenge.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: My Oracle; my better Angell.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: I have ſome extraordinary buſineſs; and am in great haſt at preſent: Servant, Madam.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: If I can but win upon young Bellamore now.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p:
O let Mr. Loveby alone for an Intrigue; I'le lay my life Madam this takes effect: For when he finds he is bobb'd of his Miſtreſs, he'l be as eager
to Revenge his wrongs as your Ladyſhip. If he boggles at Matrimony, 'tis but to give him a bond of Security; and he cannot refuſe to own you.

div.stage: Enter Dulhead above looking out of the window, Knocking and Pounding, &c.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: So ho, ho; ſo ho, ho, ho—Why Toby; Couz. Sr. John, So ho, ho, ho, ho, ho, ho;—Confounded Dog Toby—Why Toby—To—by—To—by—

div.stage: Enter Toby running with a long Rope.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Is the Devil in your throat? we ſhall have you alarm the poſſe of ſome Six of the Neighbouring pariſhes, anon; and they'l be charging you with rotten Eggs and turnip-tops;—I have been trying to force the door, but in vain;—there's no other means for your eſcape, then by this friendly rope. Clap it a-croſs one of the bars, and [throws up one end of the Rope to him. throw me down the end again.

div.stage: Dulhead getting out of the window, &c.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Mercy on us wench; what luggage of old Iron-work? what Hero Burlesquid have we yonder?

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Your humble admirer, Madam; your Country-gallant of much land Acres.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Is it that horſe-load of a fool; let's ſtand aſide a little and expect the event of this Adventure.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot Toby, be ſure hold faſt:—

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I warrant you, you ſhall come down as ſwimmingly as a Cat from a Tower in a high winde, with Bladders at her feet: (Alons Monſieur.

div.stage: He lets him down with a jerks.
Dulh. crys out holding by the Rope.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Prethee have a care, if I ſhould chance to fall—

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Your bones wou'd make but a ſorry Anatomy you'de ſay, away with it.

div.stage: Dulh. cryes out. Florella and Primroſe laughing.
Enter Sir John Oldfop Dancing and Singing: Strephon the Brisk and gay, &c.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Heavens Sir, your Couſen Sir John; we muſt diſappear—vaniſh.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsneaks, ſo I will.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: I kiſs your fair hands, Madam.

div.stage: Bows, dances and ſings as before.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: You are in a gay humour Sir John—What means the conceited Fop.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: All things are prepar'd for the Solemnity, Madam: I know you need not be directed in beſtowing your favours; when there's a certain perſon of ſome quality, whoſe merits juſtly lay claim to 'em. There's a certain Jewell, Madam, you wear about you, of too great worth to be ſoil'd by fulſome dull Matrimony, and I am convinc'd it is as good as loſt if you beſtow on one that can't ſet a true value on it. I have had the keeping of ſome ſcores of young Ladies; they knew me for a perſon reſponſable, and fit to be truſted with the treaſure:—Confound me Madam, you muſt not, ſhall not, cannot deny me.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I'le fit you for this Eſſence-bottle—But I'm reſolv'd now to carry on the humour; [aſide] Dear Sr. John my bluſhes ſpeak too much the language of my heart.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: I know Madam, you could not withſtand my jantee Inſinuating way.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Attribute it I beſeech you to your Irreſiſtable Charms, and let not my weakneſs be an occaſion of a Publick Tryumph;—Pleaſe you to walk with my Woman; ſhe'l conduct you where I'le inſtantly follow—
sp.stage: Exit Sir John bowing with Primroſe.
sp.p: Diſſolute Coxcomb: But I'le be even with the old Fool ſince he will be medling.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: I led him to my old Lady Fancifulls Chamber, and 'twas darken'd to Embolden her Squire whom ſhe had appointed to meet there: I had planted old Waspiſh under the Bed before, having poſſeſſed him, your Ladyſhip deſign'd to marry him privately; and there he lies in expectation of you, playing Bo-peep: thinking when you appear, to ſurprize you with the humour.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: We ſhall have admirable ſport, Wench.

div.stage: The Scene Changes to Fancifulls Chamber.
Old-fop and Fancifull groping after one another, Waſpiſh peeping from under the Bed.

sp.speaker: Waſpiſh.
sp.p: I proteſt, ſhe ſtays Immoderately, Udsbodikins my back's almoſt broke.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Oh I hear ſome-body; it muſt be ſhe: Dear Madam, where are you?

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Here, here Sir, ſoftly.

div.stage: they take hold of each other, and Embrace.

sp.speaker: Sr John.
sp.p: My life, my Soul, my Joy:—This is kinde, where's the Bed?

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: O Don't talk ſo, good Sir, I tremble to hear you.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Confound me; I fear ſome old hag has practis'd upon me, methinks I finde an averſion in my Love.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: Now whilſt they're in the very height of Expectation, I'le let the light in upon 'em—ha, ha, ha! I ſhall burſt with laughing.

div.stage: Waſpiſh is creeping from under the Bed; they come towards it, ſtumble over him in one another's arms; Primroſe brings in a light: Sr. John and Fancifull ſee the miſtake and ſtartle at each other.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: What's here a Succubus: Old Heccuba, is it you? You muſt like her undergo the Metamorphoſis, if you'l have your deſires Satisfy'd.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: I ſcorn your baſe diſhonourable Actions, but for my vertue and honour, you'd offer'd violence to my body, foul Raviſher.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Snoons, treachery, Murther, Curs'd Florella, Damn'd Primroſe, I'm betray'd, I'm abus'd, grant me patience, ſnoons.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: This is excellent Diverſion, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Foh, I ſhall not be ſweet again theſe two moneths:

div.stage: pulls out Eſſence, and rubs it about him.

sp.speaker: La. Fan.
sp.p: I have been gallanted by abundance of fine Perſons ſeriouſly,—But I defy the beſt of them to ſay he ever had his beaſtly will of me.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: I hate an old fool I Gad,—foh—

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Affected old Coxcomb: I'm reſolv'd I'le rid my hands of 'em all. Go you and Cajole that old Fool yonder; let me alone with this.

div.stage: The Scene ſhifts, they come forwards.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Madam, you might have pick'd out ſome eaſy credulous Fop to have made a Cully of, there are fools enough in the Town

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Think you Sir, I'd expoſe my honour to the Cenſure of that Fancifull—tho' I value your love above all things;—yet pardon me if I was ſo diſcreet as to preſerve my Reputation.

div.stage: all this while in a paſſion.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Revenge is low and vulgar; know Madam, there are a thouſand Beauties; ſigh, languiſh, burn and dye; to taſte thoſe Joys, you might have ſurfeited on. I'le Immediately to my Couſin, whom I have lock'd up from the violent attacques of that termagant Fancifull: But I'le now Enlarge him, and Conſummate the Match between you, and then Madam you lie at my Devotion.

div.stage: Waſpiſh is fretting: Spies Primroſe, puts the trumpet to his ear.

sp.speaker: Waſp
sp.p: Snoons; not a word yet, not a word yet; I'le be Reveng'd, Snoons, ſnoons.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: My Lady bad me tell you, ſhe's extreamly ſorry for this Diſappointment, and is come to beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Florell. Curtyſing
sp.p: Sir, 'twas my unhappineſs this unlucky accident fell out;—But pleaſe you to walk with me, I have a Parſon within ſhall make me yours for ever.

sp.speaker: Waſp.
sp.p: Udsbodikins; ſay you ſo, I proteſt, ſay you ſo, very well, very well—Come then, pretty Mrs. Florry, I'm Impatient, Udsbodikins, come, Mrs. Florry, come, come.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot, 'twas well my Couſin Sr. John miſt me: What forſooth you thought to make a noddy of me, Udsneaks, there's old Waſpiſh;—I'le bully him. Hum, buzz—

div.stage: Dulh. walks by him; hits him on the Shins with the end of his Sword.

sp.speaker: Waſp.
sp.p: How, how, Udsbodikins what means this?

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Mum Budget—

div.stage: twirls his hat round his head.

sp.speaker: Waſp.
sp.p: Confounded villain; he affronts me, Snoons. Let me go, Snoons, Revenge, Snoons.

div.stage: Exit Florella with Waſpiſh and Primroſe.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Should Sr. John have met with him now, I'm loſt for ever. O he is here. [aſide]—Sweet Sir., I thought you wou'd not have diſappointed me ſo.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p:
Nay forſooth I muſt confeſs I was woundily in fault; but I was lock's
up by my Couſin Sr. John; and after Toby had Releas'd me, by his advice, I ſcamper'd off to ſecure me from him; we have plotted a woundy revenge againſt him Udsfoot: and to let you know what 'tis; I'm reſolv'd to marry you forſooth!

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Oh heav'ns!——

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot you ſhall not deny me; If you do I ſhall be terrible angry: hum, hum, hum, [ſtruts] Toby has procur'd a Parſon within on purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Oh happy day! O promiſing hour of balmy pleaſures; Oh how my heart throbs and trembles with the impetuous Sallies of my blood—

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Come along forſooth; I'de give an hundred pounds to meet my Couſin Sr. John now, I cou'd be monſtrouſly valiant Udsfoot, hum, hum, hum!—

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: What, have you nooz'd your Fool?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I cannot anſwer poſitively; but by this he's in the hands of a Canonicall retailer, a Marriage-Broker; a fellow that will go through-ſtitch, with his work.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I expect Florella here Inſtantly: Yonder ſhe is I think.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Pray heav'ns it prove a fit ſeaſon to ſow the Seed of Love

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Baſe treacherous Villain: and am I now betray'd? was this his pretended friendſhip?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Faithleſs Inhumane Craftmore; are all his mighty Boaſtings come to this. Proteſtations and vows were only made by him I finde to be broke again: O Faithleſs Deſerter, who now glories in his guilt and triumphs in my wrongs.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Madam; I perceive your misfortunes hold ſomething of proportion with thoſe of mine.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: If I may believe what you have utter'd; the killing Circumſtances are juſt the ſame.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: So, ſo, they begin to cloſe;—You're made for ever you little Dog Toby; down on your Marrow-bones, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Wou'd you Contribute to the deſigne; there might be ſome ways found out yet to leſſen our miſeries, at leaſt. Suppoſe a Lady of a plentifull fortune, and a tollerable face, ſhou'd fly to you for protection, you cou'd not ſure be ſo cruell as to refuſe her.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: She's my own, if ſhe hold on thus. [aſide] Faith, Madam, I think not, was I ſure ſhe wou'd take no advantage of it.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir, if I lay by the Modeſty of my Sex;—Then I beg, I intreat you wou'd own me; and to ſecure you, take this In it is contain'd all that can Entitle me to an Eſtate.

div.stage: gives him a box with writings in't, He looks in it.
