sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: And this Madam, you deliver into my hands, to Juſtify the right I have to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I thank you kindly, Madam, I have Caught you at laſt. I faith—now let your faithleſs diſloyall Lover enter.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: O I ſhall never brook the ſight of him I fear:

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I warrant you Madam:—ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Come Madam; look upon him; he's no ſuch terrible man.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: I underſtand you not.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: I hope my fickle Miſtreſs that neither this my diſguiſe, nor long ſickneſs caus'd by your unkindneſs, nor the diſtant Clime to which I was baniſh'd by your capricious humours, can have render'd me a ſtranger to your eyes.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Oh heavens, Craftmore: [aſide]—O Sir, is this your trick?—but you cannot:—

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Nay, nay, humourſome Miſtreſs; you cannot fall off now; here is my man has over-heard all.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Yes, I gad Madam; and can ſwear bloodily up to the point.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: And am I over-reach't?—what was't blinded me thus?

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Dear friend much Joy to you.

sp.speaker: Dorin.
sp.p: And may I not ſay as much to your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Betray'd on all ſides; You may thank your Policy, or you had done pennance for the other two years.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: If you Command it, I cannot but obey you, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Dulhead out of his Armour with Fancifull.

sp.speaker: Fanci.
sp.p: Hem, hem!—well, this Matrimony is a moſt delicious, a very enlivening thing ſeriouſly;—hem.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Gentlemen and Ladies your Servant—I cannot finde my Kinſman, Madam.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Sun, Moon, and ſeven Stars; how do you like me now, Couz, Sr. John?

div.stage: comes ſtrutting up to him, leading Fancifull.

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: Ha! what wou'd the Impertinent Blockhead have? he is not ty'd to that Chymera; and Madam, am I depriv'd of you too, and all my promis'd Joys? where are the writings I truſted you with? you may keep your fool but not a groat Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: They're in ſafe hands; ne're ſtir, Couſin Sr. John: I ſcorn your affronts; Marriage is honourable; how do you like me now?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: They may be forth coming upon weighty Conſiderations: Seal, ſigne and deliver;—

sp.speaker: Sr. John.
sp.p: To threeſcore pounds, do you hear?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Then here are the writings Sir; when you quitted your pretentions, the Guardianſhip devolv'd upon Sir, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Dulh.
sp.p: Udsfoot Toby; we have out-witted my Couſin Sr. John moſt woundily, hea Toby:—

sp.speaker: Waſp.
sp.p: So, ſo, Mrs. Florry; 'tis very well; proteſt, the old Snake has Caſt his Skin; I'm twenty years younger then I was, Udsbodikins I am; You little leering, fleering, wriggling giggling Fubs you: Come kiſs me, Udsbodikins, come, kiſs your husband Mrs. Flory.—

div.stage: jumps and offers to kiſs her.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: Much joy to you, Sir; now you may go ſuck the ſweets of your Primroſe.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: How, how, I proteſt, Snoons, Snoons, treachery, treachery, I'm undone, undone; That Witch, Devil Florella, Carion, Strumpet Primroſe: I'le Poyſon my ſelf, Cut my throat, and leave my Eſtate to the King; Snoons, Snoons.

div.stage: pulls him by the ſleeve; puts the trumpet to his ear.
looks on her, flings her hand out of his.

sp.speaker: Loveb.
sp.p: This is all trick, and very pleaſant I'faith.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: What coupling here has been

div.stage: Prim. makes ſignes to ſpeak to Waſp. he puts his trumpet to his ear.

sp.speaker: Prim.
sp.p: What will you give me to Releaſe you Sir?

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: Any thing in the world; make thy own propoſals—ruin'd, ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Sign but this writing here, Sir.

div.stage: while he ſignes it Toby fetches the Canonicall habit and ſhews it him

sp.speaker: Waſp.
sp.p: Ay I proteſt with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: Know Sir, this was the Parſon, and this is the habit, in which he marry'd us.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: You had the firſt fruits of my Deaconſhip, I aſſure ye Sir.

sp.speaker: Wasp.
sp.p: A Dog, Confounded Villain; I proteſt I'le put you in the Biſhops Court; I'le make you do pennance for this, Snoons, ſnoons,

div.stage: Toby looks him in the face moving his lips as tho' he ſpoke, and laughing.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Well Primroſe ſuppoſe thee and I ſhould play the fool, and commit Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Primr.
sp.p: That word has a Charm in it, not to be reſiſted; by a poor helpleſs ſolitary Maid.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Agree'd then wench; our virtuous Induſtry has procur'd us enough to rent a ſingle room; and may all in good time bring Mr. Toby to ſome reverend office in his ward.

sp.speaker: Craft.
sp.p: For the ſervice done me, I'le make your life eaſy to you

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Loveby.
sp.p: Come Sir, you are not to ſtir till you have ſhook off your ill humours by a Dance.

sp.speaker: Florell.
sp.p: Well Sir; you have been too hard for me at laſt, but it is ſome pleaſure to ſee my revenge on that brace of old Coxcombs.

lg.l: May all old fools, that Wedlock do Importune,
Or Sue for love, with ours finde equall fortune:
And may all thoſe that make their Lovers tarry,
Be thus Trapan'd like me and fore'd to Marry.
